# Overall Project Weekly Summary (Jul 27 - 2, 2025)

## Executive Summary
This week was dedicated to laying the groundwork for significant future enhancements to the OP Stack, with a primary focus on initiating a major protocol upgrade for a configurable minimum base fee. # Overall Project Monthly Summary (August 2025)

## Executive Summary
August was a month of strategic advancement, focused on hardening the OP Stack's core protocol while laying the groundwork for future scalability and an improved developer experience. The team finalized key economic features like the minimum base fee, advanced the public rollout of Flashblocks for faster preconfirmations, and initiated a major overhaul of deployment tooling and testing infrastructure to support the continued growth of the Superchain.

### Key Strategic Initiatives & Outcomes

**Finalizing Core Protocol Features for Enhanced Stability and Performance**
*To make the network more economically sustainable, secure, and performant for all users.*
- The design and specification for a `min-base-fee` were finalized, a crucial feature for the protocol's long-term economic health. This multi-repository effort culminated in formal specifications in [ethereum-optimism/specs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs) and detailed security analysis in [ethereum-optimism/design-docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/design-docs).
- The public rollout of Flashblocks, a system for rapid transaction preconfirmations, was advanced by enabling it on sequencers and publishing comprehensive documentation for developers and operators in [ethereum-optimism/docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs).
- The core client, `op-geth`, was brought up-to-date with the latest upstream developments by merging `go-ethereum v1.16.1`, ensuring long-term stability and security for the entire stack in [ethereum-optimism/op-geth](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth).

**Modernizing Deployment Tooling and the Codebase**
*To simplify the process of launching new chains on the Superchain and make the core software easier to maintain.*
- A major strategic effort was initiated to migrate the `op-deployer` tool to use Forge, a standard Ethereum development framework. This will standardize and simplify the deployment process for all ecosystem developers, with initial implementation work starting in [ethereum-optimism/optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism).
- The legacy event system was systematically removed from `op-node`, significantly simplifying the core codebase and improving maintainability in [ethereum-optimism/optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism).
- The entire legacy `superchain-ops` system was removed, streamlining the repository and focusing efforts on a modern templating framework for managing chain upgrades in [ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops).

**Bolstering Protocol Security and Testability**
*To ensure the OP Stack is robust, secure, and reliable for all users and chain operators.*
- The next generation of the fault proof system was advanced with the introduction of `FaultDisputeGameV2` and significant planning for the "Kona + Cannon" upgrade in [ethereum-optimism/optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism).
- A major overhaul of the testing infrastructure, including the `op-sync-tester` and `op-devstack`, was completed to improve the reliability and coverage of automated tests in [ethereum-optimism/optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism).
- A significant milestone was achieved by completing the interop proof system acceptance tests, validating the functionality of the dispute system across different chains, as noted in [ethereum-optimism/specs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs) and [ethereum-optimism/community-hub](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/community-hub).

**Improving Developer Experience and Growing the Superchain Ecosystem**
*To make it easier for developers to build on Optimism and to expand the network of interoperable chains.*
- A new, detailed tutorial for upgrading ERC-20 tokens for use across the Superchain was published in [ethereum-optimism/docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs), a key step for asset interoperability.
- The Superchain ecosystem was expanded with the addition of new tokens like PEPE and PAGE in [ethereum-optimism/ethereum-optimism.github.io](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/ethereum-optimism.github.io) and the Arena Z testnet in the [ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry).
- The M6 results snapshot for RetroPGF was finalized, refining the metrics used to reward public goods contributors and demonstrating a commitment to sustainable funding in [ethereum-optimism/Retro-Funding](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/Retro-Funding).

### Cross-Repository Coordination
August showcased strong coordination on several key initiatives that spanned the entire project:
- **Forge Deployer Migration:** Planning for a major migration of the `op-deployer` to use the Forge toolkit was a central theme across nearly every repository. This coordinated effort, which saw immediate and proactive engagement from the community, aims to create a more standardized and user-friendly experience for launching new OP Chains.
- **`op-node` P2P Sync Discussion:** A strategic architectural discussion to deprecate the existing `req-resp` P2P sync mechanism in `op-node` in favor of a simpler, more robust alternative was held across numerous repositories. This forward-looking planning is critical for the future scalability and stability of the network.
- **Strategic Deprioritization:** A coordinated decision was made to deprioritize certain legacy tools and features, such as the event system and Kurtosis testing support. This allows the team to focus resources on higher-impact priorities like the Forge deployer and improved testing frameworks.

# Overall Project Monthly Summary (October 2025)

October was a month of significant achievement and focused preparation, as we officially concluded the Isthmus network upgrade while simultaneously hardening the protocol and advancing key features for the next major upgrade, Jovian. Efforts to improve system stability resulted in critical fixes to our transaction infrastructure and fault-proof monitoring, while a major overhaul of our testing framework will ensure greater reliability for all future development.

### Key Strategic Initiatives & Outcomes

**Finalizing a Major Milestone and Hardening the Protocol**
_Goal: To ensure the long-term stability and security of the OP Stack by completing past upgrades, resolving system-wide instabilities, and investing in automated testing._
-   The **Isthmus Upgrade** was officially finalized, marking the successful conclusion of a major network-wide initiative across multiple repositories including [optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism), [infra](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/infra), and [specs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs).
-   A major overhaul of our testing infrastructure was completed in [optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism), introducing a "flake-shaker" system and nightly fuzz testing to automatically detect and prevent unstable code from being merged.
-   Critical stability issues with the **Flashblocks** service were resolved across the stack, fixing a problem that caused lost transactions and improving coordination with external RPC providers.

**Preparing for the Jovian Network Upgrade**
_Goal: To develop and test the core components of the upcoming Jovian upgrade, which will introduce new economic models and efficiency improvements to the protocol._
-   Significant progress was made on the **Data Availability (DA) Footprint Limit**, a feature designed to manage L1 data costs. Work included updating specifications in [specs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs), implementing the logic in [op-geth](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth), and completing extensive testing.
-   A consensus-breaking change to the **operator fee formula** was implemented in [optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism), a key economic update for the Jovian upgrade.
-   Deployment tooling was updated in [optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism) to support the next generation of dispute games, a core component of our fault-proof system.

**Improving Security and Decentralization**
_Goal: To enhance the robustness of the OP Stack's security mechanisms, particularly the fault-proof system that ensures the integrity of the L2 chain._
-   The dispute monitoring system (`op-dispute-mon`) was significantly improved in [optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism) to prevent it from raising false alarms when monitoring rollup nodes that are out of sync, making the entire fault-proof system more reliable.
-   New architectural documents were created in [design-docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/design-docs) to formalize the design of new components like the Kona Rollup Node and a protocol-enshrined revenue-sharing mechanism.

**Growing the Superchain and Improving Developer Experience**
_Goal: To make it easier for developers to build on the OP Stack and to expand the ecosystem of assets and applications across the Superchain._
-   The developer experience was enhanced with a new practical guide for creating L2 rollups and a major restructuring of our documentation in [docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs).
-   A new feature was added in [superchain-ops](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops) to enable direct L1-to-L2 function calls through the Optimism Portal, improving cross-chain interoperability.
-   The Superchain ecosystem was expanded with the addition of numerous new tokens, including ATTN, MIRROR, DSTRX, RIO, and DRIP, in [ethereum-optimism.github.io](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/ethereum-optimism.github.io).

### Cross-Repository Coordination

**Resolving Flashblocks Instability**
A coordinated effort across eight repositories, including [op-geth](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth), [superchain-registry](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry), and [community-hub](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/community-hub), resolved a critical stability issue in the Flashblocks system, which is used for private transaction ordering. The fix involved upgrading core components, improving alerts, and coordinating with external RPC providers to ensure a smooth rollout, preventing lost transactions and hardening a key piece of infrastructure.

**Implementing the Data Availability (DA) Footprint Limit**
Work on this key feature for the upcoming Jovian upgrade required tight collaboration. The protocol rules were updated in [specs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs), the core logic was implemented in our client [op-geth](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth), and a suite of acceptance and unit tests were completed across repositories like [infra](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/infra) and [docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs) to validate the implementation from end to end.

**Investigating a Critical Blocker: The Cannon/Go Compatibility Issue**
A critical issue where a bug in the Go programming language (version 1.25) causes our fault-proof system (Cannon) to calculate incorrect hashes is being tracked across nine repositories. Teams from [specs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs), [infra](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/infra), and [optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism) collaborated to diagnose the problem and confirm its root cause lies in an upstream dependency. This coordinated investigation is crucial for tracking the external fix and mitigating its impact on our roadmap.

## Executive Summary
This week, development focused on enhancing the security and reliability of the OP Stack's core monitoring systems. Significant effort was dedicated to improving how the dispute monitoring service handles out-of-sync nodes, a critical step in ensuring the integrity of the Superchain and preventing false alarms.

### Key Strategic Initiatives & Outcomes

**Strengthening Protocol Security and Reliability**
*This initiative is vital for maintaining the integrity of the OP Stack, ensuring that the dispute resolution process—a cornerstone of optimistic rollups—functions correctly under all network conditions.*

-   Teams from both the core protocol and infrastructure repositories collaborated on a critical issue to define a robust solution for the dispute monitoring system. This joint effort ensures that a key security component of the OP Stack behaves correctly when encountering nodes with synchronization delays, preventing incorrect dispute resolutions and bolstering trust in the network.

# Overall Project Weekly Summary (Oct 19 - 25, 2025)

This week, the project made significant strides in finalizing the upcoming Jovian network upgrade while simultaneously advancing preparations for the future Fusaka upgrade. Key efforts also focused on evolving the next-generation fault dispute system and improving the developer experience, demonstrating a strong focus on both near-term delivery and long-term platform health.

### Key Strategic Initiatives & Outcomes

**Finalizing the Jovian Network Upgrade**
*Goal: This work locks in the features and configurations for the upgrade, ensuring a secure and predictable rollout across the Superchain.*
-   Feature toggles for the Jovian upgrade were removed in [ethereum-optimism/op-geth](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth), signaling that the scope is now settled and development is complete ([#703](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth/pull/703)).
-   A bug in the `GasPriceOracle` was fixed in [ethereum-optimism/optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism) to correctly calculate operator fees for the Jovian hardfork, resolving a previously identified issue ([#17913](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/17913)).
-   Final specifications were merged in [ethereum-optimism/specs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs), clarifying genesis block behavior and updating transaction bytecode to finalize the upgrade's technical details ([#801](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs/pull/801), [#804](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs/pull/804)).

**Advancing the Next-Generation Fault Proof System**
*Goal: We are building a more modular and flexible dispute system to support a wider variety of proof systems, enhancing the security and decentralization of the Superchain.*
-   The core contract management system was upgraded in [ethereum-optimism/optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism) to support the new V2 dispute game contracts, enabling a more flexible pattern for adding new game types in the future ([#17782](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/17782), [#17874](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/17874)).
-   Architectural refinements were made to the V2 contracts, allowing a single deployment to be used for multiple game types and improving efficiency ([#17832](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/17832)).

**Improving the Developer and Operator Experience**
*Goal: Creating clear documentation, stable tools, and automated processes is crucial for enabling builders and operators to contribute to the ecosystem effectively.*
-   A major restructuring of the app developer documentation was completed in [ethereum-optimism/docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs), improving the organization and accessibility of over 50 guides and tutorials ([#1792](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs/pull/1792)).
-   A strategic shift in local development tooling was solidified by deprecating the older Kurtosis tool in favor of enhancing `op-up` as the primary method for spinning up local test networks ([#16975](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs/issues/16975), [#17942](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs/issues/17942)).
-   New CI automation was added to [ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry) to automatically generate code and open pull requests, streamlining repository maintenance ([#1120](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry/pull/1120)).

**Preparing for the Future Fusaka Upgrade**
*Goal: By completing preparatory work on testnet, we are de-risking the future Mainnet deployment and ensuring a smooth transition.*
-   Key preparatory tasks, including the `op-geth` merge and absolute prestate updates, were confirmed as complete on the Sepolia testnet across multiple repositories like [ethereum-optimism/design-docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/design-docs) and [ethereum-optimism/op-geth](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth). Attention has now shifted to tracking the rollout for Mainnet ([#682](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/design-docs/issues/682), [#1206](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/design-docs/issues/1206)).

### Cross-Repository Coordination

-   **Upgrade Coordination (Jovian & Fusaka):** Finalizing the Jovian upgrade and preparing for Fusaka required a coordinated effort across the stack. Repositories including `optimism`, `op-geth`, `specs`, and `docs` worked in lockstep to update code, finalize specifications, remove feature flags, and close out related issues, ensuring all components are aligned for the upcoming changes.
-   **Maintaining Superchain Compatibility:** An important cross-team discussion ([#17907](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth/issues/17907)) focused on how to introduce new configuration fields for the Jovian upgrade without breaking compatibility for external ecosystem partners, particularly zk stacks. This highlights a commitment to maintaining a stable and interoperable Superchain for all participants.

# Overall Project Weekly Summary (Oct 26 - 1, 2025)

## Executive Summary
This week, the project made significant strides in preparing for the upcoming Jovian and U17 network upgrades, a coordinated effort spanning multiple teams to enhance the entire Superchain. This forward-looking work was balanced with a deep focus on improving the stability of the core platform and strengthening ecosystem collaboration, highlighted by a key bug fix developed with the Celestia team to improve alternative data availability.

### Key Strategic Initiatives & Outcomes

**Preparing for Major Network Upgrades**
_Goal: To ensure a smooth and secure rollout of new features and improvements across all chains in the Superchain._
-   Coordinated preparations for the U17 upgrade across numerous mainnet and testnet chains, including Base, Zora, and Metal, by opening upgrade-specific pull requests in [ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops).
-   Updated the core software for the Jovian hard fork by integrating new features and removing temporary toggles in [ethereum-optimism/optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism).
-   Implemented new Jovian features in the execution client, including updated receipt fields and precompile limits, in [ethereum-optimism/op-geth](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth).
-   Set the official Jovian activation timestamp across 36 network configurations in the Superchain's central registry, marking a critical step toward the upgrade in [ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry).

**Enhancing Platform Stability and Developer Experience**
_Goal: To provide a more reliable and accessible foundation for developers building on the OP Stack._
-   Created a comprehensive set of new technical specifications for core components like bridging and fault proofs, providing a canonical reference for builders in [ethereum-optimism/specs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs).
-   Made a concerted effort to improve the reliability of the testing infrastructure, fixing numerous flaky tests and hardening the developer environment in [ethereum-optimism/optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism).
-   Overhauled the documentation site's infrastructure by removing legacy systems to streamline the build process and improve content integrity in [ethereum-optimism/docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs).
-   Introduced rate-limiting on a core infrastructure service to improve performance and protect against abuse in [ethereum-optimism/infra](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/infra).

**Strengthening the Superchain Ecosystem and Interoperability**
_Goal: To support the growth of a diverse network of chains and ensure seamless operation for partners and L3s._
-   Resolved a critical bug in the `op-batcher` that improves support for alternative data availability layers, a fix developed in collaboration with the Celestia team and merged in [ethereum-optimism/optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism).
-   Expanded the Superchain's recognized assets by adding the ENSC token for the Lisk network in [ethereum-optimism/ethereum-optimism.github.io](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/ethereum-optimism.github.io).
-   Actively engaged with third-party developers to address compatibility issues caused by recent updates and began work to simplify the configuration process for L3s, with discussions spanning [ethereum-optimism/ethereum-optimism.github.io](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/ethereum-optimism.github.io), [ethereum-optimism/infra](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/infra), and [ethereum-optimism/specs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs).

### Cross-Repository Coordination

-   **Jovian & U17 Network Upgrades:** Preparing the Superchain for upcoming hard forks required synchronized changes across multiple repositories. This involved implementing new features in `optimism` and `op-geth`, updating the official protocol documentation in `specs`, setting activation times in `superchain-registry`, and staging the upgrades for individual chains in `superchain-ops`.
-   **Alternative Data Availability (AltDA) Integration:** A bug affecting the `op-batcher`'s performance with AltDA layers like Celestia was discussed across `infra`, `specs`, and `op-analytics`. The solution, developed in collaboration with the Celestia team, was ultimately integrated into the core `optimism` repository, demonstrating a healthy, cross-ecosystem partnership to solve a shared problem.

## Executive Summary
This week, Optimism made significant strides on two parallel fronts: executing near-term protocol upgrades and hardening core infrastructure for long-term stability. The U17 Jovian Upgrade was successfully deployed to test networks, while project-wide discussions focused on solving foundational challenges related to transaction batching and data consistency, ensuring the Superchain remains robust and efficient as it grows.

### Key Strategic Initiatives & Outcomes

**Advancing the Protocol Roadmap**
_Goal: To deliver planned network upgrades that enhance the capabilities and security of the OP Stack for all Superchain participants._
- The U17 Jovian Upgrade was successfully deployed to test networks, a key milestone on the path to mainnet activation. This was supported by a critical bug fix to ensure the upgrade transaction could execute smoothly. ([superchain-ops](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops))

_Goal: To improve the security, reliability, and efficiency of the fundamental components that power the Superchain._

_Goal: To empower builders and grow the ecosystem by providing clear documentation, diverse assets, and support for public goods._

The second involves improving the `op-batcher`'s efficiency during network congestion ([#18102](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/ethereum-optimism.github.io/issues/18102)) and making its configuration less brittle ([#18178](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/18178)). - **Documentation Overhaul:** A concerted effort to improve documentation quality was visible across multiple repositories. This included a large-scale quality pass in the `docs` repo, the introduction of new formal specifications in `specs`, and the start of a new documentation initiative in the `optimism` repo, demonstrating a shared commitment to improving resources for developers and operators.

# Overall Project Weekly Summary (Nov 9 - 15, 2025)

## Executive Summary
This week, the project focused on strengthening the core foundations of the OP Stack through a significant overhaul of testing and deployment infrastructure. This foundational work ran in parallel with extensive preparations for the upcoming Jovian network upgrade, ensuring the Superchain remains stable, secure, and ready for its next evolution.

### Key Strategic Initiatives & Outcomes

**Bolstering Core Infrastructure and Testing**
*To increase development velocity and ensure the long-term reliability of the OP Stack, we invested heavily in our internal tooling, testing frameworks, and continuous integration (CI/CD) pipelines.*
-   The testing framework was significantly expanded to cover more network configurations and increase fuzz testing for core smart contracts, improving protocol robustness. ([ethereum-optimism/optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism))
-   The CI/CD pipeline was optimized by migrating away from self-hosted runners and improving artifact management, leading to faster and more reliable builds. ([ethereum-optimism/optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism))
-   A new automated workflow was introduced to build and attest `op-geth` releases, enhancing the security and integrity of the client software. ([ethereum-optimism/op-geth](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth))
-   A persistent tooling installation error was resolved, and a security update was applied to core infrastructure, improving stability for developers and operators. ([ethereum-optimism/infra](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/infra))

**Preparing the Superchain for the Jovian Upgrade**
*To ensure a smooth and secure transition for the entire ecosystem, we finalized preparations for the upcoming Jovian (U17) network upgrade.*
-   Extensive configuration and documentation updates were completed for the Base Sepolia and Sepolia stacks, ensuring all chains are prepared for the upgrade. ([ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops))
-   New release notices for the Jovian upgrade were published, keeping node operators and the community informed of the upcoming changes. ([ethereum-optimism/docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs))
-   A critical testing milestone was achieved across the stack, confirming that proof validation for the Jovian upgrade is successfully integrated and running automatically. ([ethereum-optimism/infra](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/infra), [ethereum-optimism/docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs), [ethereum-optimism/op-geth](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth), [ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops), [ethereum-optimism/optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism), [ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry))

**Improving Developer and Operator Experience**
*To empower builders and support the network, we enhanced our documentation and tooling, making it easier to develop on and operate Optimism-powered chains.*
-   The Actions SDK documentation was significantly expanded with new reference pages for wallet integration and API usage, providing developers with more comprehensive resources. ([ethereum-optimism/docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs))
-   The node troubleshooting guide was improved to help operators more easily diagnose issues with their infrastructure. ([ethereum-optimism/docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs))
-   Support for zstd compression was added to `op-acceptor` images, improving data handling efficiency for infrastructure operators. ([ethereum-optimism/infra](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/infra))

### Cross-Repository Coordination

**Jovian Upgrade Readiness**
A coordinated effort across multiple teams ensured the ecosystem is prepared for the Jovian network upgrade. The `superchain-ops` team managed the low-level configuration changes, the `docs` team handled public communication, and a key testing issue ([#17303](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs/issues/17303)) was closed across six repositories, confirming that automated action tests are in place to validate the upgrade's integrity.

**Shared Protocol Optimization Efforts**
Discussions on improving core protocol performance and safety took place across the project. A key topic was the optimization of `op-node`'s communication with the execution layer to reduce "FCU spam" ([#15393](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth/issues/15393)). This collaborative discussion culminated in a concrete improvement merged in the `optimism` repository to debounce these messages ([#18234](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/18234)), demonstrating how shared analysis leads to direct protocol enhancements.

# Overall Project Weekly Summary (Nov 16 - 22, 2025)

## Executive Summary
This week was defined by a dual focus on strengthening our foundations and planning for future innovation. We executed a massive, project-wide initiative to clean up technical debt and streamline backlogs, enhancing developer focus and efficiency. Simultaneously, we laid the formal groundwork for significant new capabilities, including ZK game integration and a Light Consensus Layer, positioning the OP Stack for its next phase of growth.

### Key Strategic Initiatives & Outcomes

**Improving Project Health and Developer Focus**
_Goal: To increase development velocity and long-term stability by systematically reducing technical debt and clarifying our current work priorities._
- A massive backlog grooming effort was completed across nearly all repositories, closing hundreds of outdated or resolved issues related to test flakiness, deprecated features, and node stability.
- A coordinated review of the codebase identified outstanding tasks previously tracked only in code comments (`TODOs`). These were converted into formal issues to ensure they are properly addressed, improving transparency and accountability ([optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism), [superchain-registry](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry), [specs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs), and others).
- The developer test environment was simplified by formally deprecating the old "KT" devnet and closing dozens of related acceptance test issues in the [infra](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/infra) repository.

**Laying the Groundwork for Next-Generation Features**
_Goal: To begin the development of major new protocol features that will expand the capabilities of the OP Stack and the Superchain._
- Planning was formally kicked off for integrating ZK (Zero-Knowledge) games, with a suite of new issues created to track work on proof generation, monitoring, and challenging mechanisms in the [optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism) monorepo.
- The "Light Consensus Layer" initiative was formalized, a feature that will enable more flexible and efficient node configurations. This included adding new flags to `op-node` ([#18270](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/18270)) and creating a main tracking issue ([#18315](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/18315)).

**Strengthening the Superchain's Economic Framework**
_Goal: To enhance the economic sustainability of the Superchain and make it easier for new chains to participate in the ecosystem._
- New templates were introduced in [superchain-ops](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops) to provide chains with a clear path for upgrading their vaults and opting into the revenue-sharing model ([#1257](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops/pull/1257)).
- To improve fee market stability, bounds for minimum base fees were added to the standard configurations for mainnet and Sepolia in the [superchain-registry](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry) ([#1127](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry/pull/1127), [#1163](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry/pull/1163)).

**Bolstering Core Protocol Security and Stability**
_Goal: To ensure the core protocol remains secure, reliable, and aligned with the broader Ethereum ecosystem._
- The [op-geth](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth) client was updated by merging upstream changes from `go-ethereum v1.16.4` ([#689](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth/pull/689)), ensuring it benefits from the latest L1 developments.
- The protocol's resilience during network upgrades was improved by adding alternative recovery methods for hardfork activations in [design-docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/design-docs) ([#357](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/design-docs/pull/357)).
- A correction to the flashblocks specification was merged in [specs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs), improving protocol accuracy ([#860](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs/pull/860)).

**Improving the Developer and Operator Experience**
_Goal: To make it easier for developers and node operators to build on and interact with the Optimism ecosystem._
- The [docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs) site underwent a major navigation refactor to improve content discoverability for developers and operators ([#1872](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs/pull/1872)).
- Key guides for node operators, such as the snap sync documentation, were restructured for better clarity and organization ([#1851](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs/pull/1851)).

### Cross-Repository Coordination

This week highlighted strong alignment across teams on strategic priorities:

- **Technical Debt Initiative:** A coordinated effort, visible in `optimism`, `specs`, `design-docs`, `op-analytics`, and `superchain-registry`, involved systematically reviewing old issues and cross-referencing them with the codebase to find and formally track remaining work. This ensures that cleanup from past refactors is fully completed.
- **Strategic Feature Decisions:** A unified decision was made across multiple repositories to observe the `min-base-fee` feature's performance in production rather than conduct further simulations ([#16958](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs/issues/16958)). Additionally, teams aligned on deferring fixes for `op-node`'s EL Sync behavior until the older request/response sync mechanism is fully deprecated, avoiding redundant work.
- **Upgrade Preparedness:** The core development team (`op-geth`, `superchain-ops`) coordinated with the `docs` team to ensure that critical requirements for upcoming upgrades, such as the `cannonKonaPrestate` ([#18095](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth/issues/18095)), are clearly documented for operators.

# Overall Project Weekly Summary (Nov 23 - 29, 2025)

## Executive Summary
This week's efforts balanced foundational upgrades for future growth with a sharp focus on immediate network stability. Significant progress was made on long-term initiatives, including a new specification for Custom Gas Tokens and an overhaul of the contract management system. Concurrently, a coordinated, cross-team investigation is underway to diagnose a critical sequencer bug and address emerging performance bottlenecks on Base Mainnet, reinforcing our commitment to a secure and reliable Superchain.

### Key Strategic Initiatives & Outcomes

**Advancing Future Protocol Capabilities**
_Goal: To build the next generation of features that will enhance the flexibility, security, and scalability of the OP Stack and Superchain._
-   **Custom Gas Tokens (CGT):** Foundational work progressed to allow Superchain networks to use tokens other than ETH for transaction fees. A comprehensive specification was introduced in [ethereum-optimism/specs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs), while the core implementation advanced significantly in the [ethereum-optimism/optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism) repository, moving the feature closer to release.
-   **Next-Generation Proof System:** Strategic planning for the future of the protocol's security continued, with deep architectural discussions on implementing ZK (Zero-Knowledge) proofs. Teams across [ethereum-optimism/docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs) and [ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry) are designing the new system, including how to generate and verify proofs.
-   **Modernized Contract Management:** A major overhaul of the contract management system, OPCM v2, was advanced in [ethereum-optimism/optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism). This new architecture will simplify future network upgrades and deployments, making the system more robust and easier to manage.

**Strengthening Protocol Stability and Performance**
_Goal: To ensure the network remains reliable, secure, and performant for all users and applications._
-   **Critical Bug Investigation:** A high-priority, cross-team investigation is focused on a potential bug in the `op-node` sequencer's recovery mode that could cause the chain to stall. This effort, tracked across multiple repositories including [ethereum-optimism/specs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs) and [ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops), is critical for maintaining protocol stability.
-   **Addressing Network Performance:** New performance issues on Base Mainnet, including RPC timeouts and batch submission delays, were identified in [ethereum-optimism/optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism). This has become a new area of focus to ensure the network can handle high demand efficiently.
-   **Improving Cross-Client Compatibility:** A key milestone was achieved with the successful re-integration of `op-reth` (an alternative client implementation) into the main test suite. This was confirmed across [ethereum-optimism/op-geth](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth) and [ethereum-optimism/infra](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/infra), strengthening the diversity and resilience of the Superchain ecosystem.

**Enhancing Developer and Operator Experience**
_Goal: To provide builders with accurate documentation, powerful tools, and clear resources._
-   **Documentation and Tooling Improvements:** The [ethereum-optimism/docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs) team merged numerous fixes to repair broken links and correct outdated information. In parallel, [ethereum-optimism/op-analytics](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-analytics) introduced a new tool for analyzing fee market dynamics, providing deeper insights for developers.
-   **Community Contributions:** The project saw valuable engagement from the community, with a new contributor volunteering to fix incorrect Docker image references and add missing environment variable descriptions, improving resources for node operators.

### Cross-Repository Coordination
This week highlighted strong collaboration on several key initiatives:
-   **Sequencer Bug Investigation:** The investigation into the `op-node` sequencer bug ([#18350](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/18350)) is a coordinated effort involving developers from `specs`, `docs`, `superchain-ops`, `optimism`, and `op-analytics`, demonstrating a unified response to a critical stability concern.

# Overall Project Weekly Summary (Nov 30 - 6, 2025)

## Executive Summary
This week, Optimism made a pivotal strategic decision to integrate ZK fault proofs directly into the existing `op-challenger` system, streamlining our security roadmap and resolving a major research effort. This decision was immediately followed by a significant development push to implement the core logic for ZK games. In parallel, the team shipped critical stability fixes for core network components and continued to expand the Superchain with the integration of new chains.

### Key Strategic Initiatives & Outcomes

**Advancing Protocol Security with ZK Fault Proofs**
*Strategic Importance: This initiative enhances the security and decentralization of the OP Stack's dispute resolution system, preparing the protocol for the next generation of fraud-proof technology.*
-   A key strategic decision was made to use the existing `op-challenger` for ZK games, concluding a major research spike and providing a clear path forward for implementation ([`specs`](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs/issues/18322)).
-   A significant development effort in the `optimism` repository delivered the core logic for ZK game challenges, including architectural refactoring and new functionality for challenging proposals, reclaiming bonds, and resolving games ([#18441](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/18441), [#18442](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/18442), [#18464](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/18464)).
-   The strategy for ZK proof generation was finalized, with the task assigned to the succinct proposer, closing out a key investigation ([`superchain-registry`](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry/issues/18319)).

**Improving Network Stability and Reliability**
*Strategic Importance: This work ensures the network remains robust and dependable for all users and node operators, addressing issues that could impact performance and uptime.*
-   A critical fix was shipped in `optimism` to prevent the sequencer from stalling during network reorganizations, directly improving network uptime ([#18233](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/18233)).
-   Bugs in the `op-batcher` were resolved in `optimism` to improve its handling of large block backlogs, enhancing the reliability of data submission to L1 ([#18344](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/18344)).
-   Key stability issues reported by the community, such as `op-node` synchronization problems, are being actively tracked and investigated across multiple repositories, including [`superchain-ops`](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops/issues/18468) and [`infra`](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/infra/issues/17448), to prioritize future fixes.

**Expanding and Standardizing the Superchain**
*Strategic Importance: These efforts grow the network of interoperable chains and ensure they are built on a consistent, well-defined foundation, making the ecosystem easier to join and manage.*
-   The Superchain was expanded with the integration of Base as an executed upgrade and the completion of key setup tasks for Worldchain in `superchain-ops` ([#1312](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops/pull/1312), [#1284](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops/pull/1284)).
-   Work progressed on creating a standard `SuperchainDefinition` type within the official `specs`, which will make it easier to configure and manage chains across the ecosystem ([#867](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs/pull/867)).
-   Development began in `superchain-registry` to streamline the process of adding new chains by allowing for embedded contract artifacts ([#1172](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry/pull/1172)).

### Cross-Repository Coordination
This week highlighted strong coordination on several key initiatives that spanned the entire project:
-   **ZK Challenger Strategy:** The decision to integrate ZK game logic into `op-challenger` was a project-wide effort. The decision was tracked and finalized across issues in `specs`, `ecosystem`, `superchain-ops`, `infra`, `docs`, and `op-geth`, culminating in a focused implementation sprint within the `optimism` repository.
-   **Superchain Standardization:** The effort to formalize the `SuperchainConfig` type involved collaborative discussion across `specs`, `ecosystem`, `op-geth`, and `infra` to ensure the new specification is clear, language-agnostic, and meets the needs of the growing Superchain.
-   **Node Stability Monitoring:** Community-reported issues with `op-node` and `proxyd` were tracked and validated across `superchain-ops`, `infra`, `docs`, and `superchain-registry`, creating a unified view of operator pain points that informs development priorities in the core `optimism` repository.

# Overall Project Monthly Summary (December 2025)

## Executive Summary
December was a month of dual focus, balancing future innovation with present-day stability. We made a significant strategic leap forward by solidifying our approach to ZK fault proofs and completing a large volume of implementation work, while simultaneously dedicating resources to diagnosing and addressing critical node synchronization issues affecting network operators.

### Key Strategic Initiatives & Outcomes

**Advancing Protocol Security with ZK Fault Proofs**
_Goal: To enhance the security and versatility of the OP Stack by integrating Zero-Knowledge (ZK) proofs into our fault-proof system, a key step towards a more robust and decentralized Superchain._
-   A major strategic decision was made to integrate ZK game challenging directly into the existing `op-challenger`, streamlining development and establishing a clear path forward. This was a key outcome discussed across multiple repositories, including [specs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs) and [op-geth](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth).
-   The core `op-challenger` component was heavily refactored in [optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism) to support ZK games, including the ability to challenge proposals ([#18467](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/18467)), resolve games ([#18464](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/18464)), and reclaim bonds ([#18465](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/18465)).
-   A large volume of planning and implementation issues related to ZK proof generation, configuration, and bond handling were closed across repositories like [superchain-ops](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops), [op-analytics](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-analytics), and [superchain-registry](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry), marking the completion of a major feature epic ([#18322](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/ecosystem/issues/18322)).

**Strengthening Network Stability and Reliability**
_Goal: To ensure the OP Stack is robust and reliable for all node operators and users by actively investigating and resolving critical infrastructure issues._
-   A high-priority `op-node` synchronization bug affecting operators on Base Mainnet and other chains is under active investigation across the project ([#18468](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/infra/issues/18468), [#18510](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/infra/issues/18510)), with maintainers and the community collaborating to diagnose the root cause.
-   A critical bug in the `op-batcher` that could affect transaction processing during periods of high load was fixed in [optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism) ([#18344](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/18344)), improving network resilience.
-   A potential data consistency risk in `proxyd` that could serve stale block data was identified for a fix in January, demonstrating a proactive approach to infrastructure integrity ([#501](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/infra/issues/501)).

**Expanding the Superchain Ecosystem**
_Goal: To grow a vibrant and interoperable network of chains by integrating new partners and standardizing the configuration process for the Superchain._
-   The Superchain continued to expand with the official integration of Base as an executed upgrade in [superchain-ops](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops) ([#1312](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops/pull/1312)).
-   Progress was made on integrating Worldchain, with key handback tasks completed on the Sepolia testnet ([#1284](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops/pull/1284), [#1315](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops/pull/1315)).
-   Work began in [specs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs) to formalize a `SuperchainDefinition` type ([#867](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs/pull/867)), a crucial step towards creating a more structured and verifiable definition for all chains in the ecosystem.

**Improving the Developer and Operator Experience**
_Goal: To empower builders by providing comprehensive documentation, streamlined tooling, and reliable infrastructure._
-   The official documentation received a major overhaul in [docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs), with community guides consolidated ([#1879](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs/pull/1879)) and widespread formatting and navigation issues fixed ([#1901](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs/pull/1901), [#1907](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs/pull/1907)).
-   CI/CD workflows were refactored across [infra](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/infra) ([#519](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/infra/pull/519)) and [optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism) ([#18443](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/18443)) to improve reliability, security, and maintainability of the development pipeline.
-   The Custom Gas Token (CGT) system was formally integrated as a system feature in [optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism) ([#18405](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/18405)), removing the developer flag and making it an official part of the OP Stack.

**Supporting Public Goods through RetroPGF**
_Goal: To foster a sustainable ecosystem by funding projects that provide value to the Optimism Collective and the broader Ethereum community._
-   Work was completed in [Retro-Funding](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/Retro-Funding) to finalize the results for RetroPGF Season 8, Milestone 10, including refining data queries and weightings for onchain builders ([#87](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/Retro-Funding/pull/87), [#88](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/Retro-Funding/pull/88)).

### Cross-Repository Coordination

-   **ZK Fault Proof Integration:** The month's largest coordinated effort was the push to advance ZK fault proofs. The strategic decision to use `op-challenger` was discussed in [specs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs) and [op-geth](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth), with core implementation work in [optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism), deployment preparations in [superchain-ops](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops), and configuration updates in [superchain-registry](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry). This resulted in the closure of a large, cross-repository epic of related issues, demonstrating a unified push on a key technical priority.
-   **`op-node` Stability Investigation:** The critical `op-node` synchronization issue ([#18468](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/infra/issues/18468)) triggered a project-wide response. The issue was discussed and tracked across nearly every repository, from [infra](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/infra) and [optimism](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism) to [docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/docs) and [superchain-ops](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops), highlighting a coordinated effort between maintainers and the community to diagnose and resolve a pressing operational challenge.
